speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He calls Romeo out, saying misfortune loves his qualities and he is married to disaster. This introduces Romeo’s tragic state and the Friar’s role as counselor.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He anxiously asks what the Prince’s judgment is and what new sorrow awaits him. This shows his dread and anticipation of punishment.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He says Romeo is too acquainted with misery, then reveals he brings news of the Prince’s doom. This delays the answer to build tension.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks if the judgment is anything less than doomsday, showing his fear that it will be execution.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He says a gentler sentence came from the Prince: not death but banishment. This is the crucial revelation of Romeo’s fate.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He reacts with horror, saying banishment is worse than death and begs for death instead. This reveals his despair at being separated from Juliet.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He confirms the banishment and urges patience, saying the world is wide. This attempts to console but ignores Romeo’s emotional attachment to Verona.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He says there is no world outside Verona, only torture and hell; banishment is exile from the world, which is death misnamed. He accuses the Friar of killing him with a golden axe—a seemingly kind but fatal blow. This speech uses extreme metaphor to express his despair.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He scolds Romeo for ingratitude, noting the law demanded death, but the merciful Prince changed it to banishment. He insists Romeo fails to see this mercy. This highlights the theme of rash youth versus reasoned mercy.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He argues that heaven is where Juliet lives; even animals and unworthy things can see her, but he cannot. Flies can touch her hand and steal kisses from her blushing lips, but he is banished. He asks if the Friar has no quicker means of death than banishment, and says only the damned in hell use that word. He accuses the Friar, as a holy man and friend, of mangling him with that word. This long, emotional speech uses vivid contrasts and hyperbole to show his torment.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He calls Romeo a foolish madman and asks to be heard. This shows his attempt to regain control of the conversation.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He interrupts, fearing the Friar will speak again of banishment. This shows his fixation and refusal to be comforted.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He says he will give him armor against that word—the sweet milk of adversity, meaning philosophy—to comfort him in exile. This introduces the Stoic consolation he offers.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He rejects philosophy unless it can create a Juliet, move a town, or reverse the doom; otherwise it is useless. This dismisses abstract comfort in favor of his concrete, passionate grief.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He remarks that madmen have no ears, meaning Romeo won’t listen to reason. This underscores the communication gap between them.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He retorts that how can madmen have ears when wise men have no eyes, implying the Friar is blind to his suffering. This witty comeback shows Romeo’s despair-fueled cleverness.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar asks to discuss Romeo's situation calmly.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says the Friar cannot understand his pain because he hasn't experienced it himself. He lists his woes: youth, new marriage, Tybalt's murder, his own banishment, and despair so deep he measures his own grave.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar hears knocking and urgently tells Romeo to hide.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo refuses to move unless his groans hide him like a mist. This shows his extreme self-pity and refusal to face reality.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar grows more frantic with repeated knocking, telling Romeo to run to the study while he answers the door, exasperated by Romeo's foolishness.

speaker: NURSE
content: From offstage, the Nurse asks to enter and says she comes from Juliet.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar welcomes her and invites her in.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse anxiously asks where Romeo is.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: He points out Romeo on the floor, overwhelmed by his own tears.

speaker: NURSE
content: She says he is in the same state as Juliet—both weeping uncontrollably. She urges him to be a man and stand up, asking why he falls into such deep despair (a deep 'O' meaning a groan or lament).

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo simply says 'Nurse,' acknowledging her.

speaker: NURSE
content: She responds fatalistically that death comes to everyone.

speaker: ROMEO
content: He asks if she spoke of Juliet and whether Juliet now sees him as a murderer for killing Tybalt, who was nearly her own blood. He wonders where she is, how she is, and what his secret wife says about their ruined love.

speaker: NURSE
content: She says Juliet says nothing but weeps, alternating between collapsing on her bed and crying out for Tybalt and Romeo.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo imagines his name, like a bullet from a gun, has killed Juliet as it killed Tybalt. He asks the Friar which part of his body his name resides in so he can destroy it.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar scolds Romeo for his suicidal impulse, saying his tears are womanish and his rage beastly. He lists Romeo's blessings: Juliet lives, he killed Tybalt in self-defense, the sentence is exile not death. He urges Romeo to go comfort Juliet, then flee to Mantua before the watch is set, promising they will later reveal the marriage and seek pardon.

speaker: NURSE
content: The Nurse says she could have stayed all night listening to the Friar's wise advice, admiring his knowledge, and promises to tell Juliet that Romeo will come.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo tells the Nurse to do so and to have his beloved get ready to scold him, referring to Juliet's expected anger over Tybalt's death.

speaker: NURSE
content: She gives Romeo a ring from Juliet, urging him to hurry because it is getting late.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo feels his spirits lifted by receiving the ring, which renews his hope and comfort.

speaker: FRIAR LAWRENCE
content: The Friar tells Romeo to leave immediately, either before the night watch is posted or at dawn in disguise, stay in Mantua, and his servant will send news of any good fortune here. He shakes his hand and says goodbye, emphasizing the lateness.

speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo says that only an overwhelming joy calls him away, otherwise parting so quickly would be painful, and he bids farewell.
